entry.title: Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Over the past months Early Adopter Care program participants, were gradually ramped up with additional capabilities powered by the Embedded IoT platform. With SAP Asset Performance Management 2511, we have released the Embedded IoT functionality within SAP Asset Performance Management to all our customers and partners. Customers now benefit from an end-to-end offering that spans from sensor to process action or insights, all within SAP Asset Performance Management - achieving seamless integration of data sources and monitoring of IoT-connected assets, towards establishing condition based maintenance practices.

How does this look

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains 5 new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the IoT platform. Let's briefly run through those apps below.

 

Manage Devices

This helps you connect and manage devices efficiently. It offers a unified platform to onboard, monitor, configure, and control IoT devices throughout their lifecycle—including definition of device protocols, software & configuration management, and more, depending on the capabilities of the connected device or gateway. Many industrial environments use lightweight messaging protocols (e.g., MQTT) to collect telemetry data from machines, devices, and sensors. Embedded IoT now makes it easy to ingest and process this data as it arrives, rather than waiting for batch uploads.

With a new persona, the Device Integration Engineer, customers can now onboard, configure, and monitor devices - capabilities that were not offered in the past and were covered in other systems out side of SAP Asset Performance Management. This opens up new opportunities to get closer to the source of data, or even retrofit installing sensors that are required for maintenance purposes.

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage IoT Dashboards

For near real-time insights and reporting, the Cockpit gives you the flexibility and tools to manage and monitor device data, creating widget-based reports for individual or groups of devices. With this feature, reliability engineers can now access personalised, live, contextual IoT dashboards - unifying sensor data and events - so they detect anomalies immediately on critical assets, flexibly visualize data per their needs, and assist in driving fact-based maintenance decisions.

To quickly get started with a live data feed and exemplary dashboards, you can connect your smartphone in just a minute and explore. See how in the video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage Streaming Analytics

Streaming Rules enable enhanced condition monitoring with flow-based models to process time series data in near real-time at individual data point level. This allows for monitoring within the IoT platform, to derive new indicator values, and also triggering of rules within SAP Asset Performance Management. This continuous, real-time feedback loop allows reliability engineers to respond proactively to critical events and implement monitoring and dashboards themselves using low-code tools — capabilities not possible with batch-based monitoring. For more details, have a look at the What's new blog from the 2510 release.

 

For a quick glimpse in how it is working, you can watch this video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Map Devices to Technical Objects

To use the time series for asset management purposes, the sensors from the IoT platform need to be contextualized into the asset semantics using the Digital Twin Manager. The application allows to map devices and their sensors (the OT world) to their corresponding technical objects and indicators from SAP Asset Performance Management (the IT world). Once the connection is established, data is automatically made available into charts, rules engine, and stored into the data lake from SAP Asset Performance Management.

Navigate to technical objects along the technical object hierarchy

Assign measurements from a device to an indicator

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

IoT Platform Administration

Users seamlessly navigate to the applications with out-of-box configured Single Sign-On, and also for data archiving (see Digital Twin Manager), everything is setup automatically. However, some configurations are still relevant for Administrators and can be configured in the IoT Platform Administration application. Examples are the data forwarding between systems, or configuration of Certificate Authorities for device certificates administrators. With the Data Broker, administrators can now setup continuous data feeds between landscapes, i.e. to achieve a near real-time data ingestion into quality / test environments based on incoming data from the production environment.

What's next

Please stay tuned over the next weeks as we publish more articles showcasing the respective capabilities. You can't wait to get started? Check out this recently published blog that describes a brief end-to-end scenario from sensor to insight, using a free simulator app for your mobile phone. See how quick it is to monitor asset conditions, define failure thresholds, and generate maintenance requests using SAP Asset Performance Management.

entry.title: LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) Implementation - Data Transfer to new Standard Fields
entry.content:
When implementing LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) for the first time, you notice that some field mappings have hardcoded fields from SuccessFactors Recruiting, which cannot be modified to other fields. This happens because there's backend mapping between LinkedIn and SuccessFactors for certain fields. As LinkedIn expects to receive certain values for specific fields, an internal mapping defines how each value is sent. As a result, it is not possible to change the mapping to other Recruiting fields.

You can find the full list of field mappings and whether each one is editable here: Field Mapping Information

For example, industries and employmentStatus from LinkedIn are mapping to industry and classificationType accordingly in Recruiting, and the mapping cannot be changed.

This requirement can create implementation challenges, as some fields linked to these mappings are not used by customers, and they may have other standard or custom fields where the same information is stored.

This blog explains how to move the existing data into the fields required for the mapping using Integration Center. For example, if a customer does not use the employmentStatus standard field but has another field with the same information, they must still map and fill employmentStatus to implement LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC).

NOTES:

  • This integration needs experience with Integration Center and Recruiting configuration, and it is meant to be handled by Implementation Partners or Admin Users who have an implementation background;
  • The integration described below may behave in different ways on different systems. Please make sure to test all steps in a lower environment before moving anything to Production;
    • For better results, we suggest testing first with a small number of records before updating all of them.
  • Integration Center may not support updating all records in one single run if the number is higher than the tool's limit. We strongly recommend reviewing Integration Center limits before creating the integration: 2742107 - Integration Center: Frequently asked questions
  • As a best practice, avoid creating one integration for more than one field mapping, as this may cause performance timeouts.

STEPS:

  1. Go to Admin Center > Integration Center > My Integrations;
  2. "+ Create" button > More Integration Types;
  3. Select the following setup:
    • Trigger: Scheduled
    • Destination: SuccessFactors
    • Source: SuccessFactors
    • Format: OData v2
  4. Select the entity;
      • For Candidate Profile entity, you can use the entity CandidateLight to bypass required field validation
      • For Job Application, you can refer to the KBA Required attribute on Application fields via OData API - Recruiting Management
      • For Job Requisition, you can add the property "isDraft" to the mapping, making sure to pass TRUE. With this value, you can make your update without providing all mandatory values on the Job Requisition.
    • If the following criteria is not meet, the update may fail.
  5. On "Options" tab, fill all necessary fields
  6. On "Configure Fields" tab:
    1. Change the view to "Field Mapping View"
    2. Link the source field with the new standard field; - For example, you are mapping your existing standard OR custom fields that holds up the Employment Category to employmentStatus field, you need to link the existing field from the left column to the employmentStatus field in the right column. Here's an example from the columns (The entity here is Candidate):
      You need to drag and drop the field.
    3. Repeat the same steps to the ID field by linking the field from the left column to the right column
      • IDs per entity:
        • Candidate ID - candidateId
        • Job Application ID - applicationId
        • Job Requisition ID - jobReqId
    4. Once the mapping is done go to "Filter and Sort" and exclude any anonymized record, otherwise the system will considered anonymized records, which don't support updates:
      1. Click on "Browse" button
      2. Entity Tree View > Select the "Anonymized Flag"
      3. Add and filter by 0 (0 is the value for "Non-Anonymized)
    5. You can skip the "Scheduling" tab as the integration is meant to be executed one time only;
    6. "Review and Run" tab:
      • Click on "Run Now"
      • Wait the integration to complete
      • Verify any possible errors and fix

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content: Thanks, Lakshmipathi! This isn't a consignment business. The material was sold, supplied (for now only virtually) and invoiced in SAP. After the materials are delivered and invoiced, they must remain in our company's custody in our warehouse until the customer has space to receive it. Since the material is very expensive and not just a single unit, it's necessary for us to maintain visible control in SAP of each material and unit once we make the "virtual" supply to the customer. As the ownership is transferred in SAP, the control must be done off our accounting books, know how many units of each material we still have, what was physically delivered (and how many units), once the material has really left our warehouse. Hours after writing my question here, I was informed that the material has already been invoiced to the customer, so now we need to perform outbound delivery and goods issue, and then “re-enter” all that material into SAP ASAP, to be able to do the already explained control in SAP. Some one told me over the weekend a special “customer plant” must be created, But I'm not sure if this is the correct way to do it (*) and then how the material should be entered into SAP so that it's handled the way I explain above. (*)= If it's correct, I also don't know what’s special I need to request for the plant to be created correctly and for the material is visible and handled/tracked as non-valued.

entry.title: Re: Client copy when table mismatched
entry.content:
When I couldn't clone due to:
Field MERKS1 in Table HRP1511 is different between systems, copy cannot proceed 

I was able to workaround this solution when in SAP Easy Clone tool, to go to hidden menu bar of Edit -> General Settings -> Easy Clone General Settings -> and setting Difference in a File / Field found == "Continue processing with a difference in a File /Field" then hitting save and running the clone again.  I hope this answer helps someone else out like it did for me.

For additional info, I was able to confirm field MERKS1 was of different length between 2 environments using:

SE14 --> HRP1511 --> Check (F8) -> Database Object -> Fields

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @Marco_Mueller 

I am the certification owner for BDC. I can answer your questions.

Passing grade for the BDC assessment is 60%. This is shown on the start page of the certification before you begin and it is also shown as a reminder if you fail.

After asking you a question, the AI will keep quiet while you provide your answer. You can speak for as long as you wish and the AI will never interrupt you. When you have finished answering, the AI will wait approx. 5 seconds and if you don't say anything else, it will assume you are finished and will then move on to the next question.

You submit the exam by pressing Save and View Analysis:

After a short wait, you see your score:



Once you reach the pass score you cannot take the assessment again (e.g. to improve your score). If you fail you can try as many times as you wish within the 2 hour time limit until you reach the pass score. 

You say you reached 80% - so you must have pressed the Save and View Analysis button because that is the only way you can see your score. But you say you failed.  Well, you certainly met the pass score. How were you informed that you failed?

entry.title: Re: Current Support Status of MultiCash Format in SAP S/4...
entry.content:
Good day @JuanseVal 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Bank Statement Processing, Map Format Data for Incoming Files from Banks, How to Create a Format Mapping, Data Format Conversion in Outbound and Inbound Transactions

Check out Blog: Bank statement in XML format

In summary to your questions, the public cloud does not support MultiCash and you cannot activate it as standard import format. For you to use MultiCash statements, you must transform the file preferably into CAMT.053 or MT940 before you import. The SAP integration Suite or an external converter will enable you do that. Your customer can consider XML mapping if they receive MultiCash in XML form.

This conversion method ensure you stick to the public cloud’s clean-core approach, and it provides the standard integration pattern for banks that still provide MultiCash.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Materials are invoiced and ownership has legally passed to the customer, but physically they remain in your warehouse under your custody until the customer calls them off. You need visibility in SAP without keeping them on your company’s books.

So the recommended approach would be

Once the delivery is created, just save it and do not perform goods issue.  By doing so, that stock would be blocked for that customer and cannot be diverted to other sale orders or customers.   Of course, system will allow you to invoice before goods issue and for that, set routine 11 under "Copying requirements" in copy control configuration.  As and when, customer wanted to have, you can perform goods issue.

Now coming to your “customer plant”, the challenge I could see is you already created the sales order, delivery, goods issue, and invoice in SAP. Ownership has legally passed to the customer. You then “receive” the stock into a non‑valuated custody plant for visibility. Later, the customer asks you to physically ship it. But: there is no open sales order anymore, and billing has already been done. So how do you create a delivery from the custody plant? Of course, here also, you can explore VL01NO to create another delivery from "customer plant".

To explore "Customer Plant" option, try with the below approach but I am not sure on this

Create a special plant, sometimes called a “customer plant” or “custody plant”. Assign it as non‑valuated in customizing so postings there don’t hit your books. After the outbound delivery and goods issue from your normal plant, you immediately “receive” the same material into this special plant. This way stock is visible in SAP under the same material number. It is tracked by quantity. It is not valuated (ownership is with the customer). When the customer requests delivery, you create a delivery from this custody plant to the customer. Here, I am not sure, with which movement type, system will allow you to perform Goods Issue. Test and explore with multiple permutation combination.

entry.title: Re: Need To Add a Custom Field into Import Supplier Invoices
entry.content:
Dear @jerinsteev,

Question 1.

Yes, but only in a very restricted way.

SAP explicitly documents that the Import Supplier Invoices app (F3041) can be extended with Custom Fields but only fields created with the business context Accounting: Coding Block

Key points from SAP Note:

  1. Create the custom fields in Custom Fields (F1481) with business context:
    • Accounting: Coding Block
  2. In the User Interfaces tab, enable: (This is the problem because I can't see it in the screenshots)
    • Manage Journal Entries
    • Manage Supplier Invoice
  3. Publish the field.
  4. Download a new template in Import Supplier Invoices app

More details below in SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3452028

Question 2.

For adding CFL custom fields to the Import Supplier Invoices template, no additional extension objects, OData extensions, or communication scenarios are required

Question 3.

Yes, there is a very direct SAP Note on exactly this point.

Special G/L Indicator is not supported in Import Supplier Invoices app

More details from SAP Note and SAP Community:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3657638

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/payload-examples-for-api-journal-entry-post/ba-p/13392342

Also SAP Note documents that some fields in the template are visible but ignored during upload, and SAP plans to remove them from the template

More details below from SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3613252

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Subcontracting delivery MESSAGE ME151 (0 item(s) posted)
entry.content:
Why it happens would be because of the following:

In a subcontracting PO, the finished material is ordered, but the BOM components must be assigned in the PO item (via item detail → “Components” tab). If components are not maintained, ME2O has nothing to deliver.

ME2O checks stock of the components in the supplying plant/storage location. If stock is in a different location or batch, the system won’t pick it.

Subcontracting delivery uses movement type 541 (transfer posting to subcontractor). If the delivery type or movement type customizing is incomplete, items won’t post.

entry.title: How template based approach is helping Life Sciences customers adopt SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Life sciences industry is increasingly adopting public cloud solutions such as SAP Digital Manufacturing, to enable smart, connected factories, and enable next generation of AI innovations. While cloud solutions provide clear benefit in terms of scalability, no-technical debt, and rapid deployment – the validation of these introduce unique challenges.

Public cloud solutions differ from traditional on-premises or private cloud solutions as the infrastructure and platform is supplier managed, and updates occur on supplier’s schedule (quarterly for SAP Digital Manufacturing). Customers while inheriting many controls from supplier (SAP) remain accountable for compliance. This can result in ballooning validation costs, as with every new site and every release customers need to demonstrate that they continue to operate within regulations.

Here a template base validation approach provides a structured, repeatable strategy to address these challenges efficiently.

Core Principles for this approach

  1. Process first modular template:  The validation templates should focus on testing standardized, end-to-end processes (not technical UI screens). Customers may modularize these based on process (Dispensing, Sampling etc), so local rollouts validate only deltas to the module. The approach is based on performing validation of the global template once, and then validate deltas during rollouts, and releases
  2. Risk-based and outcome-focused validation:  As also recommended by GAMP V, a risk based approach should be applied to select what needs full local validation. A ranked and modular approach can be used to split validation into smaller risk-aligned lanes.
  3. Automate validation artifacts and test execution: Digitize test case management, traceability, and evidence capture. This allows validation templates to be rolled out with minimal manual documentation.
  4. Governance and shared responsibility: Clearly define roles for template owners, local leads, and cloud providers; document responsibilities in a RACI matrix.

Common challenges & mitigations

When implementing the template approach some challenges to lookout for:

  • Challenge: Templates are too rigid — sites need many exceptions, resulting in no cost savings .
  • Mitigation: Design configurable templates (parameters, toggles), and track which options cause site variance.
  • Challenge: Incomplete supplier qualification for cloud / third parties.
  • Mitigation: Document SLAs, security controls, SOC/ISO audits, and if possible perform on-site supplier assessment.
  • Challenge: Manual, paper-based validation artifacts that slow rollouts.
  • Mitigation: Use digital validation platforms and automate testing that can capture evidences (Tricentis Test Automation)
  • Challenge: Not taking advantage of fixed cloud release cadence.
  • Mitigation: Formalize release impact assessments and maintain a prioritized regression pack mapped to template processes. Allocate resources for validation in advance (as the schedule is known).

 

How DHC Uses and Extends the Template Approach

DHC, an SAP partner, has expanded these industry best practices to develop validation templates specific to SAP Digital Manufacturing and regulated industries. These templates have enabled regulated customers to validate SAP Digital Manufacturing and its underlying infrastructure efficiently, supporting global rollouts across multiple production sites while ensuring lower Total Cost of Validation.

A notable example is DHC’s work with a regulated industry customer, where the validation templates developed during the pilot became the foundation for enterprise-wide rollout. These templates executed through agile sprints supported by an industrialized, repeatable validation process, helped customer roll out three templates covering different production types. As SAP Digital Manufacturing undergoes frequent major releases (quarterly), DHC implemented a change management process as a part of the template approach that leverages SAP Digital Manufacturing’s Service Catalog and What’s New viewer allowing quick and efficient change impact assessment. 

This industrialized approach towards change management and validation allows customers to remain compliant through frequent software updates associated with public cloud solutions.

 

Why this matters for life sciences

Life sciences organizations must reconcile fast cloud innovation with strict regulatory expectations. A template approach — when designed around processes, risk, and automated validation — provides the repeatability and auditability something that regulators expect. This balance of process discipline + modern tooling + governance is what SAP and our partners such as DHC recommend.

Partner Profile:

DHC Dr. Herterich & Consultants GmbH specializes in GxP compliance and the validation of IT systems in regulated industries. Further details - SAP Partner Finder

Hello @JimLee209,

You have the flexibility to configure Parameter 1 of payroll function P0169 to align with your specific business requirements. For instance, if you set it to END, and your payroll period ends on 01/15/2025, it is necessary to ensure that the BN603 option has a start date of 01/15/2025 or earlier.

This example referenced a scenario where the configuration date on P0169 fell in the previous year within the payroll
period. 

Best regards,
Gisele

entry.title: Mastering the AI Mindset - Co-Creating the Future of AI & Customer Experience with SAP CX
entry.content:
Introduction

When looking back on the last few decades in the business world, we noticed revolutionary technologies have come along. Steam power changed the way we produce goods, electricity took scaling to a new level, and the internet reshaped the way we connect and do business and...here we go again - Artificial Intelligence is now changing how we behave and also do business. The reality is here: organizations and individuals must rapidly adapt, leveraging agility and resilience to augment human capabilities in every sales call, commerce site, and customer interaction; therefore, the question is: how your people and AI will co-create value together and what that means for the way you operate, decide, do busines, and will deliver results - going forward.

That said, in this blog, we’ll explore the mindset shift required to fully embrace AI and show how SAP CX Business AI Capabilities - across SAP Commerce Cloud and Sales & Service Cloud (V1 and V2) - can become a catalyst for this transformation.

 

The Mindset Shift AI Demands

This shift is emotional before it is operational.

People's emotional responses can be intense when shifting to a more AI-driven work environment. Coming to terms with the idea that AI may replace them is something that strikes fear into the hearts of many, and will feel overwhelming for a few.  Others, however, will light up at the prospect of new ideas; it's natural for some to believe it may power their performance.

In fact, if we put it in perspective, humans have been adapting to AI since its boom, and here are some examples of human personal usage:

 

AI generated

 

Hence, that is where the bridge to business really begins. The same curiosity that drives us to adopt AI - to save time, learn something new, or make our lives a bit easier - is what companies need to encourage within their culture & mindset.

Leaders don’t need to chase every shiny new tool. They need to notice the moments where AI can ease pressure, help people think differently, or give them back the time to focus on what actually matters. When those experiments start to feel natural, when curiosity becomes confidence, AI stops being some distant idea and simply becomes part of how the organization works.

That’s the real mindset shift: when AI moves from concept to companion, enabling people and businesses to grow together.

The companies and teams will be led into the future, and the leaders who will thrive are the ones who help their teams move from fear to possibility, from control to collaboration, and from task to outcome-focused mindset.

 

Augmentation, not replacement.

Let’s be clear: in the CX world, AI doesn’t replace the human element — it elevates it.

AI takes away the repetitive, low-value tasks so people can focus on what customers truly care about, for example: empathy, transparency, judgment, wisdom, and trust - all uniquely human qualities.

Think of AI as a second brain: summarizing, suggesting, forecasting, preparing groundwork, and accelerating execution. When we embrace this partnership, the impact becomes visible across all CX areas:

 

  • Commerce: content that used to take weeks is now produced in hours.
  • Sales: teams are no longer stuck in spreadsheets - they have insights and preparation done for them.
  • Service: customers receive instant answers with human escalation when needed.

In essence, we start every task with a machine-generated foundation -  the “bare minimum” already done, so humans can focus on what only humans can do: adding context, judgment, and real-life perspective.

AI frees people to do their best work, powered by human traits that technology can support but never replace.

 

SAP CX: Where the Mindset Meets the Workflow

There is a consistent message SAP CX AI connected to SAP Commerce Cloud, Sales Cloud, Service Cloud - AI works best when we redesign our processes to be around augmented work.

Examples of that mindset in action:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud: AI drafts product content, suggests improvements, guide and support the shopper relying on Agentic AI - while humans can focus on refining brand voice, enhancing experience & powerful personalization.
  • SAP Sales Cloud: AI highlights next steps, key signals, brainstorm discovery, quickly sum up key points & Agent AI supporting Quote creation from emails - while humans can focus on building relationships and closing more deals.
  • SAP Service Cloud: AI summarizes, proposes responses, suggests resolutions, and quickly categorizes incident requests via Machine Learning or GenAI - while humans can focus on handling tickets/cases with proper empathy and ease escalation.

Hence, the companies winning with SAP CX aren’t “using AI“. They’re working with AI - challenging it, reimaging their business process and workflows, and partaking in the early adoption care programs as visionaries together - with SAP.

 

Purpose-built AI that adapts to your unique challenges – A simple and exemplary Self-Check

If your AI initiative is stuck, it’s usually because one of these six elements is weak:

-> If you can’t say “yes” to most of these, pause the build. Fix the foundation. Then scale.

 

Change Management: The Decisive Factor in AI Adoption Success

Coming from the world of the known and complex change management area, AI is also technology (enhanced one, though) so the transformation is not just about rolling out new systems, it's changing people's mindset and underlying behaviours.

Thefore, also here, the foundation is imperative to address - What really gets results is explaining why AI matters, training people to think alongside it, starting small and showing off the benefit, like measuring outcomes, and addittionally, celebrate stories that show the human and AI working together, which is basically what gets people on board, and makes them feel they have a place in the future.

In short terms, here is what we may explore:

  • Explain the why, not just the what
  • Train people to think with AI, not fight against it
  • Start small and show quick wins
  • Measure Adoption & outcomes, not just usage in testing AI
  • Celebrate human + AI success stories

You see, it’s not because AI is complicated that people resist it - is usually because they don't see themselves in the picture. As a leader, you have to show them that there is a place for them.

 

Daily Rituals to Embed the Mindset 

Small daily rituals are great for embedding a mindset, because practice makes it perfect:

  • Begin workshops or internal discussion with: What could CX AI do for us in our line of business? Quick wins? Low complexity use case to start with?
  • Practice active listening in daily interaction:  How people are reacting – what is their sentiment – feeling about the AI value and adoption?
  • Leverage providers to learn at every interaction:  Ask your AI provider - how can you help my company, my business? Workshops, sharing experience & support -  SAP has been doing it! Check here some examples of Commerce Cloud or Sales & Service Cloud adoption journey playbooks and AI mindset workshops are ready for you!
  •  Regular reviews, ask: has AI improved our outcome? Analyze the results & compare – current vs target.

To ground this in practice, the image below summarizes some essential Do’s and Don’ts that can help teams adopt AI with clarity and focus:

 

AI generated.

 

 

Quick Wins First, Ambition Second

To reinforce what we’ve discussed so far — and to avoid chaos or project setbacks — it’s essential to focus and prioritize quick wins. AI can truly be a game-changer, driving impact in areas like summarization, content creation, search and personalization, request classification, recommendations, and automation of repetitive tasks. Start by mapping your quick wins, prove the value early, and then scale with confidence.

It is almost certain that massive “AI for everything now!” initiatives often lead to disorder rather than progress. Sustainable success starts with a strong foundation and clear priorities.

 

Useful Assets & Recommended Readings

  • Artificial intelligence for the real world: A blueprint for business integration
  • SAP research reveals AI to deliver a 31% return on investment
  • A practical guide for maximizing AI ROI
  • Economic Validation Study: Analyzing the Economic Benefits of Using AI-Powered SAP CX Solutions Natively Connected to SAP ERP

 

Closing: The Future Is Not Human vs Machine – at least not today 🙂

The companies that will thrive in the future are those that will say "AI is a tool that works -  for me", "AI can make suggestions, but I'm the one who creates", "AI can speed up processes and I'll take the lead".  We are still in the Copilot / Second brain Era - Let's enjoy it and make a valuable use of the AI attached to our business activities.

….which leads to the final message: It's not about outsmarting the technology; mastering AI is really about changing your way of thinking, learning, and working. Those who seize an AI-driven mindset will move more swiftly, serve better, and create CX experiences that are etched in their customers' minds.

entry.title: Calling SAP API Management from SAP Cloud Integration Using API Proxy URL & OAuth Authorization.
entry.content:
This guide explains how to connect SAP API Management (APIM) with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using an API Proxy URL secured by OAuth 2.0 authentication.

NorthWind Link: https://services.odata.org/northwind/northwind.svc/ 

1. Create API Provider.

2. Create API Proxy - To Generate an OAuth Authentication Token.

3. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

4. Create API Provider.

5. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData. 

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.

<!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

OAuth 2.0 - To verify the OAuth Token generated.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

Assign Message:

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Update >> Save >> Deploy

6. Create Product & Add both the API Proxies.

7. Create a Subscription for the Product created.

Copy the API URL, KEY and Secret for future use.

8. Create an Integration Flow.

Content Modifier: Pass Authentication Details in Header

  • client_secret: from the subscription 
  • client_id: from the subscription 
  • response_type: token
  • grant_type: client_credentials
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Body: grant_type=${header.grant_type}&client_id=${header.client_id}&client_secret=${header.client_secret} 

Request Reply - HTTP 1: For Token Verification.

Content Modifier 2: For the Passing of Authorisation and API Key.

Content Modifier 3: Pass Bearer Token

Header: Bearer ${header.Access_Token_Value}

Request Reply - HTTP 2: Pass the endpoint URL of the API Proxy.

It's time to test.

For Token generation:

OAuth 2.0

Hit Send >> 200 OK

Debug >>

Trace:

The integration between SAP Cloud Integration and SAP API Management using OAuth 2.0 has been configured and tested successfully.

entry.title: Re: COMMIT WORK AND WAIT slows down system performances
entry.content:
COMMIT WORK AND WAIT slows down the system.
It forces SAP to fully complete the update task before moving to the next material that creates amassive bottleneck issue. If it's only 20k you can just use Commit work, if it's more than that you can split in containers and do parallel task which will be easier. I have faced one issue long time back, this is how i resolved.

This can already be done. Quantities are processed by Project Billing and, when properly configured, are transferred to the subsequent Sales Billing procedure. When setting up the Billing Profile, the following options are available:

  1. Transfer Costs Only
  2. Transfer Costs and Quantity
  3. For Costs <> 0: Transfer Costs and Quantity
  4. For Quantity <> 0: Transfer Costs and Quantity
  5. Transfer Quantity Only

Best regards,

Andreas

entry.title: Differences between DDL and DML in HANA
entry.content:
DDL: It refers to Data definition language which is to define or change the structure of a object. Below are the few examples of DDL actions

CREATE - This privilege is to create database objects like tables, schemas 

ALTER - This privilege is to alter/modify the structure of a object like table

DROP - This privilege is to delete the database object like DROP TABLE statement 

DML: It refers to Data Manipulation language which is to manipulate (create/modify/delete) the data inside the object. Below are the few examples for DML actions.

INSERT - When a user is given access to INSERT privilege on top a table, then user can insert new record into the table

DELETE- When a user is given access to DELETE privilege on top a table, then user can delete a record from the table

UPDATE- When a user is given access to UPDATE privilege on top a table, then user can update an existign record of a table

#SAPHANA #DDL #DML

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Thanks once again dear Lakshmipathi!

Regarding the recommended approach, the material must be completely supplied out, because the material is invoiced and at that moment, our accounting books must show the total transfer of ownership, leaving the stock of that sale at 0, with nothing pending (so the first process must be ended performing the goods issue). This is not the doubt, the questions come after that process, and that's where the challenge comes in.

Regarding the “customer plant” challenge, the process I heard about over the weekend is precisely we have an already created the sales order, delivery, goods issue, and invoice in SAP. Ownership has legally passed to the customer and then the stock is “received” into a non‑valuated custody plant for visibility and when the customer asks later to physically ship them, a “Delivery free of charge sales order” must be created using the customer plant/storage location, so an outbound delivery can be created and complete then the physical supply performing the corresponding goods issue… The process sound logic to me and I'm starting to think that if the sales scenario is as I described at the beginning, it seems to me there wouldn't be any options... but I still really appreciate having confirmation before requesting the creation of a customized "customer plant" as non-valued. If the described process is confirmed, my doubts are reduced to some few practical things, such as, once the material leaves the valued plant, how should be the customer stock entry into the non-valued plant be done... that is, only manually with MIGO? or is there a way to avoid doing it manually? When requesting the creation of the "customer plant" as non-valued, do I need to pay attention to anything regarding the Storage location that I assume should also be created? Finally, in the sales order "Delivery free of charge" type, I see several types of "item categories"... are there any suggested types or, conversely, any that are not recommended? Is there anything else to consider that I might be overlooking?

entry.title: Using Insights in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager — Part 3 of a Series
entry.content:
How Insights Fit into SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager

For customers
Insights represent data-backed findings about how processes perform today, where bottlenecks exist, and where the greatest value potential lies.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager brings these insights together from process mining, benchmarking, documentation, and expert knowledge.
They form the evidence base used to:

  • identify opportunities
  • prioritize initiatives
  • assess value potential
  • track improvements over time

For partners
Insights create a foundation for integrated diagnostic and advisory solutions. Partners can use the platform’s APIs to:

  • embed insights from external analytics engines
  • push process mining findings directly into initiative planning
  • automate enrichment of transformation workspaces with benchmark and KPI data

This makes insights an essential layer for partner-built accelerators, methodologies, and assessments.

What an Insight Represents

An insight is not a fact for its own sake. It is a decision-enabling observation such as:

  • cycle time deviations
  • rework hotspots
  • compliance violations
  • best-practice gaps compared to industry peers
  • segments of a process with high variation
  • cost or value leakage points

In SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, these signals are transformed into structured, reusable knowledge tied to objectives and initiatives.

How to Use Insights Effectively

  1. Establish your evidence base
    Gather insights from all relevant sources — Process Insights, Process Intelligence and Benchmarking systems
  2. Centralize insights in the system
    SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager provides one place where insights are stored, organized, and linked to transformation work.
  3. Link insights to initiatives
    Every well-formed initiative should be backed by explicit insights. This ensures initiatives are based on real need, not assumptions.
  4. Feed insights into continuous improvement
    After implementation, new insights should inform adjustments, refinements, or creation of new initiatives.

What SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager Helps Avoid

  • Initiatives chosen by opinion instead of evidence
    Insights make the prioritization process fact-based and transparent.
  • Overlooking high-value opportunities
    Benchmarking and analytics make performance gaps visible.
  • Losing knowledge during handovers
    Centralized insights preserve organizational memory.
  • Lack of outcome measurement
    Insights tie improvements to measurable changes in KPIs.
  • Fragmented understanding of process behavior
    The platform aggregates data from multiple sources into one coherent view.

Why Insights Matter

Insights reveal where performance deviates, where value is trapped, and where the organization should focus its efforts.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager turns raw analysis into structured, actionable knowledge — linking it directly to objectives and initiatives so decisions are grounded in reality, not intuition.

With insights, organizations shift from reactive problem-solving to proactive transformation steering.

entry.title: Adapting the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap for Different Project Sizes
entry.content:
Not every customer journey looks the same, even more so when it comes to SAP Cloud ALM. Some are small, starting with one functionality. Others are bigger, transitioning the entire landscape from Solution Manager. There are also the ones that are huge and multi-layered, combining different projects (Operations, Implementation, Transition) and SAP cloud solutions (i.e., SAP Cloud ALM and S/4 HANA). 

No matter the scope or the size of the project you are implementing, the SAP Activate Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap is ready to adapt and help you coordinate the effort needed and the different sequence to be followed. In this blog post, I intend to share some tricks to help you manage and adapt your project without forgetting some important tasks along the way. 

The first thing you need to know is that the Road Map Viewer offers you the option of filtering your roadmaps’ deliverables and tasks accordingly to Phases, Workstreams, Product, Tags (see more on the Important aspects on SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM blog post), and Roles. This may reflect an overall view of what your activities would look like during the project, or help you work on a need-to-know basis. 

When it comes to the visibility of the project in SAP Cloud ALM, you will also have the option of assigning the different tasks to your team members and marking as ‘Not relevant’ the ones you will not be executing. This means you will be able to adjust the tasks the roadmap is offering you to your needs based on the size and scope of your project. It will also simplify your view on the Guided Implementation functionality in SAP Cloud ALM (see more on Optimize SAP Implementation with SAP Activate Methodology and Guided Implementation in Cloud ALM). 

Regardless of the project size, the Project Management deliverables and tasks are key to help you define your scope and strategy, plan and execute your project. They will also help you analyze the completion of the activities essential for each phase of the project within the Phase Closure and Sign-Off deliverable by executing the Quality Gates. 

For small projects, your focus will be on organizing them well and executing them efficiently and quickly. Therefore, we emphasize the importance of the following four tasks: Define Implementation Strategy, Create a Document Repository for the Implementation Project Team, Direct and Manage Project Execution and Confirm Backlog. These tasks will help you define a clear and strong scope and strategy, execute them effectively and maintain the stakeholders engaged and accountable during the transition. 

When implementing larger projects, besides these tasks, we also recommend you focus on the tasks Set Up Project Team Logistics and Infrastructure and Create Project Schedule and Budget right at the beginning of the project to keep your team on time and on budget, as well as to offer all the needed resources along the way. Besides that, the deliverables Execution and Monitoring of Project are available at the beginning of the Explore, Realize and Deploy phases, which will help you organize and monitor your progress as well as mitigate risks and address issues earlier, and the deliverable Sprint Planning and Execution, which is available in the Realize phase, will help you plan your sprints and iterations. 

While planning your transition either through SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation, SAP Cloud ALM for Operations or both, you may have different journeys, but know that the SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap will be here to help you adjust and even scale. With the right adjustments, this roadmap becomes more than a methodology – it is your personalized path to a confident and successful transition.

entry.title: Re: Is Integration Architecture EA discipline– or how do we see it?
entry.content:
Hi @wek. 

Thanks for sharing your feedback and let me try to provide some more clarity on some points I made.

  • On TOGAF artifacts - neither SAP EAF (as a framework) not SAP LeanIX (as a tool) are really 1 to 1 with TOGAF. Let's just take an example of ADF - we may say SAP EAF is leveraging on ADF phases, but its just not there. Also, no such a thing as artifacts specific for each ADF phase in SAP LeanIX, although many SAP LeanIX artifacts can be used for EA work should we "tailor" a bit TOGAF...
  • If I talk on "strictly" TOGAF artifacts, my experience would take me to Sparx EA (as a tool), or ArchiMate (for build-by-myself).
  • But none of this matters, as I am not "ridged" TOGAF follower - its been a while since I've started following more Lean EA approach - i.e. AppHaus etc.
  • SAP EAF is great - because it takes a lot from TOGAF, but it also takes a lot of "lean" from SAP AppHaus. Also, SAP LeanIX is a great EAM product - and I like  (among other things) because its an EAM tool on its own.

I am not sharing any criticism to SAP LeanIX - on a contrarily; I am sharing some facts (or at least my views, from my long-term experience). 

On the integration, indeed this is great article/review from HammadSharif1  (I've kudo it). I've been following ISA-M from the very beginning - but as I do my work with heterogenic landscape (both SAP and non-SAP systems), I was sharing more generalist approach is some of my articles (i.e. Integration Architecture Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4; or i.e. EDA and Compossible Business Architecture).  But indeed - great inspiration does come ISA-M and SAP Integration Suite (incl. AEM) in general.

Again, big thanks for sharing your feedback - and I hope I was able to clarify some of my points.

entry.title: Re: Field "XXX" in table /1OM/ODM_OEIT_STR_300 is specifi...
entry.content:
Here are a few things you can try:

  1. Run DDIC Consistency Check
    Go to:
    SE14 → Utilities → Database Object → Check
    This sometimes highlights the exact inconsistency inside the structure.

  2. Clear DDIC Buffers
    Use transaction:
    /$SYNC or /nbuf
    Then try activating the structure again in SE11.

  3. Activate Parent Objects
    Activate the higher-level objects where this structure is used (tables, includes).
    Sometimes the inconsistency lies in the parent and not the structure itself.

  4. Try “Where-Used” Cleanup
    Use SE11 → “Where-used list” and check if any dependent include/structure still holds the old field definitions.
    Open them and activate manually.

  5. Regenerate Using SE80 → Utilities → Regenerate Object List
    This triggers a deeper activation and sometimes resolves the “partly active” status.

  6. SAP Note 1624942
    This Note usually works only when the structure is locked in an inconsistent state.
    If Z_UNLOCK_R3TR_TABLE didn’t help, then the issue is not a lock but a DDIC version mismatch.

  7. Transport Level Check
    If this happened after an update/transport, check STMS → Import History → Logs.
    You might see warnings related to this structure.

  8. If everything fails
    Sometimes only this works:

    • Temporarily rename the duplicate fields

    • Activate

    • Then rename them back
      This forces the system to rebuild the structure internally.

If you can share which exact fields are duplicated, it might help narrow down if it’s due to an include or an enhancement.

@Suneetha,  

pre-tax contribution is also checked by 402g limit. So, if you have put the limit in 'total max.' in V_74FH_C, when employee reaches the limit of 23500, catch-up contribution will be pre-tax.

With 'ROLL', ROTH catch-up doesn't come out for lower income employee when he contributes both pre-tax and ROTH. However, I may need to re-test this scenario with the max pre-tax 23500 to see if this would make a difference. 

Euna

entry.title: Re: Build 8228/8229 Enhancements To Unload/Reload DB Lowe...
entry.content:
There is nothing in those bug releases that would affect the size of a rebuilt database.  

The reduction is size from a rebuild is going to depend on two key aspect - one, the page utilization, and two the number of free pages.  Unfortunately, both metrics are impacted when deletes occur so are not reliable in determining if there were unwanted deletes.  You could translate the transaction log(s) and verify that only the desired deletes were performed as part of the maintenance.

entry.title: Re: Difference between PSM (Public Sector Management) and...
entry.content:
Dear @RP1,

  1. „Standard” Public Cloud:
  • Use the suffix apps, for example:
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules – Asset Postings
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules – Service Documents
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules – Group Journal Entries
  • SAP Help page: Manage Substitution/Validation Rules describes these contexts and explains that you define rules per business context

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/8837a41d09744bf7963720c41c9f5b83.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e6175604fc874bfe84aa14d2f9ae1fbd/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4406')/S35

Public Sector Management (PSM):

  • Use Manage Substitution and Validation for Public Sector (F7603)
  • It is listed in the Public Sector Management help node together with Rules for Substitution and Validation in PSM

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F7603')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/273eac91cdab45c1ad2b11839cfd4f35.html

SAP Note 3583820: “App Manage Substitution and Validation Rules cannot be open”:

    • Says that the generic app Manage Substitution and Validation Rules (F4406) without suffix is not the correct one to use
    • Recommends using the app with suffix: Manage Substitution/Validation Rules Journal Entries
    • States that the generic app is planned to be removed in CE2508

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3583820

 

  1. Business contexts:

Standard rules:

  • Documented in Rules for Substitution/Validation help topic
  • Lists contexts like:
    • Journal Entry Business
    • Group Reporting
    • GR Journal
    • other financial and logistics contexts

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/8837a41d09744bf7963720c41c9f5b83.html

PSM:

  • Documented separately in Rules for Substitution and Validation in PSM
  • This page and the PSM node list PSM-specific contexts, for example:
    • Integration with Contract Accounting (FI-CA) and rule-based distributions
    • PSM-specific account assignment flows (public sector budgeting, etc.)
    • Links to applications like Rule-Based Account Assignment Distribution and PSM-relevant Asset Accounting scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/50c85005148941e1a3e6ebe13b4c9f7f.html

  1. Industry / scope dependency:

Standard app:

  • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules help is under Finance and is available in any Public Cloud system with the relevant Finance scope

PSM app:

  • Public Sector Management (PSM) is an industry solution
  • Public documentation for Public Cloud states that PSM features for budgeting, funding and grants are part of a public-sector-specific solution that must be activated as an industry scope

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/39258e361aa8474a89da8f57fc9fd3a4.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Email trigger delay after Job Requisition approval
entry.content: Honestly, there’s no built-in way to send an email 15 days after approval, so you’ll have to work around it. Most teams handle this with some kind of scheduled check (via Integration Center or another external job) that looks at approved requisitions each day and sends the email once they hit the 15-day mark. Not the most elegant solution, but it’s pretty much the only reliable way to get a delayed notification in SF right now.

entry.title: Re: Difference between PSM (Public Sector Management) and...
entry.content:
Dear @RP1,

  1. Same rules framework / component
  2. Same rule model
    • Business context
    • Event (for example “Before save”, “After check”)
    • Rule type (Validation / Substitution)
    • Precondition ->Action / Message
  3. Same developer extensibility
    • For custom logic
    • For custom function

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/cf92618cf8f849999fc08a03dc53c1a5.html

The engine is the same, the Public Sector variant is not a separate technical framework, it’s the same rules framework with different business contexts and fields like I wrote in first answer.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Achieving Best-in-Class Invoice Exception KPIs in SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing
entry.content:
One of the clearest indicators of efficiency in an AP organization is the percentage of invoices that can be processed without an exception. Best-in-class performers consistently achieve 85–90% (or higher) invoice-throughput with zero exceptions. Many SAP Ariba customers operate far below that—often without realizing how much time, cost, and user frustration gets tied up in exception handling.

As part of the SAP Ariba Solution Value Advisory team, we work with customers every day to improve adoption and unlock measurable business value. And one consistent theme we see?
Within SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing or SAP Ariba Invoice Management,  when the “invoices without exceptions” KPI is low, it’s usually a sign that key reporting insights or powerful configuration options aren’t being fully leveraged. Many customers set these tolerances and exception rules at their go-live and never revisit them—even as their supplier base, purchasing patterns, and business priorities evolve. The good news is that by analyzing the right reports and adjusting targeted configuration settings, this KPI can be improved quickly and sustainably.

Let’s walk through why this matters, what you should measure, and how to improve it using SAP Ariba best practices.

Why This KPI Matters

Improving your exception-free invoice rate isn’t just about efficiency—it directly impacts:

1. Faster Invoice Cycle Times

Fewer exceptions mean fewer delays. Suppliers get paid quicker. AP teams get out of firefighting mode.

2. Stronger Supplier Relationships

Consistent processing builds trust, predictability, and reduces the back-and-forth inquiries.

3. Lower Operating Cost

Exception handling is expensive. Every unnecessary rework loop adds labor hours.

4. Better User Experience

Buyers, receivers, and AP processors spend less time resolving issues and more time on strategic work.

5. Clean Data Feeding Analytics & Automation

A cleaner invoice process unlocks more opportunities for automation, validations, and future optimization.

Step 1: Measure What’s Really Happening

Before solving problems, you need a clear look at them.

I always recommend customers start by running the following in SAP Ariba:

Exception Reports by:

  • Exception type

  • Supplier

  • Commodity

This gives a precise view of where your exceptions are coming from. Often, 80% of issues originate from 10–15 suppliers or a handful of commodities.

This becomes your roadmap.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Supplier

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Supplier

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each supplier.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Commodity

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Commodity

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each Commodity L2.

Interpret the Results and Identify Where to Act

Once you’ve run your exception reports by supplier and commodity, the real value comes from how you use the findings. This is where customers often unlock quick wins.

Start by reviewing:

  • Which suppliers generate the highest number of exceptions

  • Which commodities consistently trigger the same exception types

  • Patterns across PO types or line items

In most organizations, a small group of suppliers or categories is responsible for the majority of exceptions. This makes your next steps much more focused and targeted.

Use the Data to Drive Configuration Improvements

If you see that receiving exceptions are concentrated around certain suppliers or commodities, this is a strong indicator that your receiving process may not fit how those suppliers operate. For example, many high-volume, fast-shipping suppliers (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, IT accessories, etc.) ship and invoice so quickly that end users rarely have time to receive the items manually.

This is exactly where SAP Ariba’s configuration options can help.

Step 2: Strategy & Configuration Options to Improve Your KPI

Below are the most effective levers that customers have used to reduce invoice exceptions and move toward best-in-class performance.

1. Use Auto-Receiving for High-Velocity, Low-Risk Suppliers

If you see a high volume of receiving exceptions for certain suppliers—especially those who ship quickly (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, safety, IT peripherals)—auto-receiving can significantly improve your throughput.

Why this works

Many of these suppliers ship and invoice same-day. That leaves almost no time for end users to receive goods manually. Auto-receipt ensures:

  • Fewer receiving exceptions

  • Faster invoice processing

  • Less burden on casual users

How to configure

Auto-receiving can be based on:

  • Supplier & Supplier Part Number or by only Supplier 

  • Commodity

2. Review and Adjust Tax Exception Tolerances

Tax exceptions are common, especially in jurisdictions where suppliers calculate tax differently or round amounts differently.

How to improve

  • Review your current tax variance tolerances

  • Identify suppliers consistently triggering small variances

  • Adjust tolerances to realistic levels aligned with procurement policy

This can be strategically relaxed only where justified—not globally.

3. Evaluate Shipping Cost Tolerances

Shipping exceptions often occur when:

  • The supplier charges small shipping amounts not included on the PO 

  • When outside a stated percentage tolerance of the invoice amount

Options

  • Set reasonable shipping % tolerances

  • Use flat-rate dollar tolerances for specific suppliers

  • Update templates for certain commodities where shipping is always variable

4. Leverage Invoice Exception Overrides (By Supplier or Commodity)

This is one of the most under-used but highly effective tools SAP Ariba customers have.

What They Are

Invoice exception overrides allow you to set:

  • Different tolerance percentages

  • Different dollar limits

For specific suppliers, commodity codes, or currency.

Why It Matters

Most exceptions are not systemic—they are concentrated. Overrides let you tune the system where the problem exists, without weakening global controls.

Examples

  • For a trusted supplier with a predictable pattern, allow a slightly higher price variance.

  • For a commodity where tax always fluctuates (e.g., services), apply more flexible thresholds.

  • Ensure to adjust amount tolerances per currency

5. Work With Suppliers When Exceptions Follow a Pattern

Sometimes exceptions are not a configuration issue, but a supplier process issue.

Consider supplier-facing improvements such as:

  • Reinforcing PO-Flip usage

  • Ensuring suppliers invoice based on PO quantities only

  • Updating supplier enablement documentation

  • Aligning catalog pricing with contracts

  • Negotiating tax and shipping behavior

Remember—suppliers want faster invoice processing too.

Step 3: Communicate Improvements and Track Progress

Once you’ve implemented changes, measure the impact:

  • Exception rate by supplier month-over-month

  • Top 10 exception drivers (before vs. after)

  • Auto-receive success rates

  • Percentage reduction in tax/shipping exceptions

Customers who follow this approach typically see:

  • 20–40% reduction in exceptions within 90 days

  • Major improvements in user satisfaction

  • A measurable boost in straight-through invoice processing

Final Thoughts

Improving your “invoices without exceptions” KPI is not about relaxing controls—it’s about applying the right controls in the right places. The strategies in this article come directly from working with many SAP Ariba customers, across industries, who have successfully increased adoption and reduced AP workload through targeted process and configuration optimization.

If your KPI is below best-in-class, use this as a starting point. A few focused adjustments can create a major lift in processing speed, supplier satisfaction, and AP efficiency.
